editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.q: Mathew. xviii. Wo to the world becauſe of offences, for it muſt needs be that offences ſhall come, but wo bee to that man by whom thoffence cōmeth.
div.p: Imprynted at London in Fletſtreete, at the ſigne of S. Iohn Euangeliſt by Thomas Colwell.

div.head: To the Ryght Worſhypfull▪ moſt vertuous, and my very good Vncle: Mr. Anthony Colclough Eſquire: G. Colclough his welbeloued kinſman wiſheth health & proſperitie▪ and in the law of God a perfecte knowledge.
div.p:
COnſideryng (Ryght welbeloued) that ſince ye firſt age of our forefather Adam and his poſteritie, great was the iniquitye which daylle more and more increaſed in the hart of man: again vewyng what a vice is Idlenes the moother of Deuocion, ioyned with her handmayd Ignorance: I thought it conuenient to keepe my ſelfe vnblameable & excuſed of theſe two, ſo great, ſo wicked and deteſtable miſchiefs, leſt ye in any one iot I ſhould be reproued in leanynge to theſe two ſo notorious vices. Pondring againe, the
great vnfained frendſhip, which I haue receaued at your handes, I could not but ſhewe mine indeuour in requitynge the ſame, although not by outwarde gifte, yet by the inward affection, which lieth and hath alway remayned in mee, to the intent to recompence (though as it is in deede but ſlackly) your good will manifeſtly ſhewed vnto mee. But now as touching the matter from the tyme of our firſt Progenitoure, to the yeares of Noah that faithfull ſeruant of God, ſuch was the diffuſed condicion of all eſtates, in followynge theyr wanton luſtes and froward deuiſes, that God was ſore diſpleaſed and his anger was vehemently kindled agaynſt theim, ſo that were it not that his fatherly wiſdome had ſayd I will not alway ſtriue with man ſeeyng hee is but duſt, yea & repented him that hee had made him, were it not I ſaye for this hee had ben deſtroied for euermore.

Yet ſtill did hee leane to his owne way neglectinge his maker, ſo mercifull and ſauourable a God, ſo that iuſtly hee ſent a Flood which couered the whole face of
the earth, in whych inundation onelye Noah and his poſterytie was ſaued, beyng preſerued in the Arke, Since which Flood and the fyre of Sodoma and Gomorrha, mannes corrupted nature was ſuch, that yet he ſeaſed not to offend that now in the laſt age and yron world, manifold be thoffences which are dayly committed, to the grief of Gods elect. Yea ſince the two former worldes, the Golden, & Braſen, which wer both nought, and yet the one worſe then thother, ther remaineth yet this yron obſtinat world, in wickednes exceeding bothe. And yet vndoubtedly gods word (God be praiſed therfore) is as much preached nowe as was then, but fewe be ryght followers therof. Wherfore becauſe I haue inuayed againſt it, I praye you iudge not amiſſe of mee bycauſe here by you maye perceaue whyche bee the ſelye ſheepe, and whyche the rauenynge Wolues, and how to make a ſeperation betwene them both. Deſyrynge you to accept
my good wyll in thys my ſmall and barbarous indeuoure and hereafter I ſhalbe encourage to attemt a greater enterpriſe. And thus fare ye well.

lg.l: GOod Reader yeld thy liſting eare
let hart and minde be preſt,
For thinges right wondrous thou ſhalt heare
and learne to chooſe the beſt.
Of euery thinge which nature wrought
A Mirrour cleare is hither brought,
O • ech miſdeede which in him lurkes,
and how hee doth them vſe:
And thou ſhalt ſee how all his workes
And if that ought be done amiſſe,
then let me beare the blame
But if the truth expreſſed is,
For ſure as neare as I could geſſe
And that which I do here expreſſe,
Wherfore iudge as it is in deede,
And this a greater gift ſhall breed,

div.head: Wo to the world bycauſe of offences. Ma • . xviii.

lg.l: IF Care doth cauſe men cry
If Wo doth make men wayle
If ioyfull mirth may not preuayle
nor make their woes the leſſe,
ſith ech man liues in care,
Well may I ſhew my carefull paine,
Sith all men liue in woe,
Now let my mourninge lyfe be ſo,
For why I finde and proue,
Men do not as them ſhould behoue
For marke and you ſhall ſee,
I feare me this the cauſe wilbe,
that all do come to nought.
Then will you ſay in litle ſpace,
as true it is in deede,
The greateſt miſchiefes day by day,
But inwardly euen all a bout,
much filth ther may you finde.
Ther inward parts you may wel know
Like Hawkes ſo is their ſight,
Wheras before they liued in peace,
now care doth keepe the grounde.
And though yea with the beſt,
Though their eſtate aboue the reſt,
And though in all his workes,
God frames all to the beſt,
Yet rooted in the hart ther lurkes,
The wealthier the man is known,
though all I do not blame,
Yet many do refuſe their food,
But where that may bee wrought,
Like Owles in mids of night,
which may not ſee by daye,
So darkened is theſe buſſardes ſight
O man wher is thy minde,
who biddeth thee liue in woe,
Or els why art thou thus vnkinde,
O thinke that he which wrought,
the cloudes, the ſea, the lande,
And ech thinge to his order brought,
Which made the foule, the fiſh, the beaſt
And ech thinge els repoſde in reſt,
for foode did make the fielde,
the foule and fiſhe to ſhield.
Which made the mouthe to ſpeake,
the hand to worke his will,
If men his lawes do euer breake:
may not he plague them ſtill.
Which made the eye to ſee,
Shall not he plague and puniſh thee:
but theſe thinges ſtill to ponder,
It ſhould be ſure thy proper kinde,
May not the ſame thy ſinnes conuart,
as it doth like him beſt.
For why thus hath he ſayd:
As ſcarlet, yet they ſhalbe made,
To call vs to repent our crime,
And if it may poſſible bee,
And if ſo be the biblinge pot,
as I do thinke no leſſe,
I thinke the ſame ſhall ſurely fall,
For God is now euen ſurely bent,
to take your cup a way.
The wine ſo ſwete in taſt,
The lord a way ſhall ſurely caſt,
and from your lippes it pull.
And if he did it ſpeake,
What ſhal we do his lawes which break
To houle and morne, to weepe & waile,
which ſtill do breake his lawes.
God will not ſtill his wrath forbeare,
I feare the iuſt ſhall ſpeed,
far worſe for ill mens ſake,
And God will as I thinke in deede,
For wher the word is tought,
Small goodnes ſemeth to bee wroght,
As though it were of worthy price,
Wheras the truthe for to confeſſe,
tis but • o cloke their ſhame.
Such carping care ſuch toyling payne,
I feare me ill wilbe the lucke,
which all this care doth beare.
And ſure I doubt it ſore,
it was not ſayd in vaine,
A certaine man full rich ther was,Luk. 12
And thus in time it came to paſſe,
when as he liued in peace.
A bounding with all ſubſtance great,
Vnto his ſoule thus doth he ſaye,
bee glad and take thine eaſe,
For thou art bleſt for many a daye:
But oh thou foole ſayth God the Lord,
thou knoweſt not what ſhall fall,
The goodes wher with thou now art ſtord
And in the ſelfe ſame night,
his goodes of ſo great powre,
And he him ſelfe of ſuch a might,
This is the end of ſuch,
Of Gods good giftes which had ſo much,
Therfore he doth them cleane deſtroye,
and catch them in his net.
And are not ſuch in deede,
a ſcourge iuſt for ther crime,
Yes if it were well knowne,
I feare ſuch ſeede is depely ſowne,
But what or who they bee,
or how their lyfe they leade,
I wiſhe with all my hart to ſee,
Yet neuer was ſe rite the crime,
which now a dayes doth flow.
Which way ſo euer you ſhall paſſe,
Which cauſeth as I greatly feare,
his word to beare the blame.
Thoſe which his holy lawes do breake
and call to God for grace.
Leaue of and that with ſpede,
And rather helpe him at his nede:
Turne not a way thine eare,
when he ſhall ſighe and grone,
But with a louing countnance heare,
Such one doth ſure a good intent,
Full litle ſure is the reliefe,
With empty wombe yea all day longe
that man ſhall not be harde,
When as he crieth, his brothers care,
And when likewiſe was euer more,
But oh who dare once moue,
when rich men do not right,
Or who is he which dare reproue,
a man ſo great of might.
And eke the iudge ſhall playnly hear •
his faultes to be ſo great.
Good Lord how in his cauſe,
Shall then be hard intionted lawes,
to rid him out of paine.
And ſhall I ſay the trothe,
that his ſhould be the right,
Yea thogh ech man might ſe,
Yet is he now both franke and fre,
Yet may ech man be bolde,
Of many men they are controld
Yf once they do but hyſſe.
He ſhalbe thruſt out of his doore,
And if he moue his lippes,
He ſhall haue many tanting nips
And though his goods be ſmall,
Although it may releaſe his thrall,
Good Lord how great is the aſſault
of thoſe which beare him grudge.
And ſee the ſword his harte to perce,
which all waies did them good.
of whom they beare ther name,
Wheras it is but a pretence,
thoſe ſame which be of me,
Therfore ſayth God the Lord,Eſdras. xvi.
And they ſhall fele my heauy ſword,
which put my ſheepe to payne.
Wo vnto thoſe which laye.Eſay. v.
And houſe to houſe ioyne euery daye,
This ſame is in mine eare,
the Lord of hoſtes hath ſaide,
And likewyſe none ſhall them repaire,
But oh the world doth them forgo,
I thinke the time was neuer ſene,
And that to good mens grieffe,
as ech man may well know,
For litle ſure is the reliefe,
Some proude be in ther minde,
and ſome be proude in harte,
And ſondry kindes you may well finde,
wher with God hath them bleſt,
And ſome be proude if that ther gaines,
and ſome to worke ther ſpite,
And ſome againe in ſkilfull bookes,
And though that bookes do yelde,
Yet is the Lord the ſtedfaſt ſhielde,
Yet many haue a great deſire,
And though their landes be baſe,
They thinke it is no comly grace,
Though in his purſe ſmall good he haue,
That when as he ſhould walke,
The ingnorant might ſay and talke,
loe ther a man of might.
But God which made the harte,
He ſeethe when thou doſt depart,
Therfore the Lord which ſaide,Eſay. iii.
Thy Daughters heads bald ſhalbe made
By cauſe ther pride is much,
There minſinge in the ſtreat is ſuch
Ther earinges vailes and other thinges
Ther launes and all thinges of the beſt,
Ther yonge men eke ſhalbe deſtroid,
and none ſhall waile the dead.
may not they now be ſene?
Are not ſuch things ſtill more and more
as ryfe as they haue bene.
No not the leſt of all,
but now is to be founde
And that which then was very ſmall,
if ſo it be her will,
And eke in all thinges her deſire,
Why might not I ſtraight will ſhe ſay,
That men might ſay whē them they ſee
But that ther chaſtnes ſhold be great,
But now twixt man and wyfe,
What great debate, what daily ſtryfe,
But who doth liue in peace,
Or ſay his hart is well at eaſe,
ſuch one I thinke is bleſt,
The hart it is in deede,
Yet hath it ſurely greateſt neede,
Fyrſt at the hart thou muſt begyne,
And if thou could once ſee,
the hart with in thy breſt,
Full many thinges there placed be,
But man doth rune hys courſe,
And worldly things do make him worſe
Which man to ſuch corruption bringes,
For looke and you ſhall ſee,
So that the world might called bee,
the vale of woes in deede.
The rich man doth the poore deſpiſe
Contemned is the man of need,
But Ioſeph did not ſtill,Geneſis. xxxvii.
Nor God did not ſo frame his will
to keepe him ſtill in paine.
And though he bare the ſmart,
Though he through their deſpiteful hart▪
In Egipt was he loued tho,
And when the dearth was great
Hee gaue his brethren foode to eat,
to ſet his owne at eaſe,
But God doth looſe theyr yrou chaines,
For he which was ſo kinde▪ Acts. xii.
So that the chayns which did him binde.
And he which made a way,Daniell. vi.
Doth guide as it is ſeene all way,
Such myſchiefe as now dayly bredes,
Such witty braines as neuer were,
And finally the world through out,
Such vices as doth now appeare,
For knowne we be euen by the ſame,
which doth with in vs breede.
Like as the tre is knowne,
And as the fruct right well is ſhowne,
by trees which doth it beare.
So may the man be ſpide,
And by the thinge he may be tride,
which in him is moſt ryfe.
his pride is ſet in ſight:
And as the Dronkard by hys can,
And as the poore man doth appeare,
As rich men by their wealth,
As ſound men likewiſe by ther helth,
As ech thyng to be brief,
Whych bringeth eyther ioy or grief,
Thus by the out ward ſhow
in things which moſt are vſed,
The inward hart you may well know
Although it were no more then need,
yet might I thinke it much.

that it may not be ſpide,

for long it may not bide.

to ſmite him with the ſworde.
Thus though with his owne kin,
Will God thinke you with ſmal regard
Who ſo doth thinke the ſame
For God rewardes with open ſhame

and call to God for grace.
And that lykewyſe therby may growe
Yet do it not for go,
but vſe it more and more:
Vntill they feele the endles wo
Bicauſe they breake Gods holy lawes
That what Adulterar they might finde
But wee do thine it meete,
Thoffendours to ſtand in a ſheete,
While thus they thinke in hart,
This is nothing of any ſmart
to turne me from the ſame.
Thus do they ſerue their wicked fleſhe,
Now be they ſure encouraged more,
as doth the wiſe man ſay,
For many ſtrong men haue bin ſlaine,
For ſure it is a vice,
as no good eares may heare
In whom where it doth bide,
For ſuch one ſeekes on euery ſide
to bring his frend to payne.
And by his ſubtle miſchief ſought,
Wherby hee thought to worke his will,
To ſecke his father Dauids wracke,
and hee to bee the king.
But God, which ſawe his hart
So that he felt the greater ſmart,
And as in bataile hee did ride,
For why? it was exceedinge faire,
Thus God doth turne the though • es,
And brynges their counſels clene to noughtes
The one becauſe hee ſought to clime,
So that I iudge it ſo,
Who ſought to breede his fathers wo,
How manie do deſerue the wound
But if the hart were ſpide,
I thinke Ambicion ſhould be tride,
if it ther in did lye.
But God which made the hart
and eke the eye did frame,
May well reuenge with cruell ſmart
For why? when they ſhall ſee

And neuer are they well in plight,
till like they bee of name.
Right ioyfull when they ſhall ariſe

But while this lumpe of clay,
doth rule yea all a bout,

When as ſuch miſchiefe doth encreaſe,
Such ſuckinge ſtill of poore mens blood,
For if a poore man ſhall,

to ſee his debtes be payde

Althogh with care they wold be faine,

Yet can not God for beare,
And that vnto thy brother deare,
This thinge thou ſhalt not do,Deut. 23
The loue of God ordaind it ſo,

haue weightes both great and ſmall,

as he him ſelfe hath ſaide.
But as full true it is,

and leaue them clean in dede.
